title: Transitioning Your Child to Self-Carry Epinephrine

content: After my son’s first anaphylactic reaction and subsequent visit to the emergency room, followed by a visit to an allergist, there was one big takeaway that I knew I’d be responsible for daily. Of course, there were the obvious responsibilities in caring for his safety, reading ingredient labels, making meals often from scratch, and looking for signs or symptoms of a reaction. One major responsibility that I additionally needed to be resolute in was to always have a set of epinephrine with him.

Since he was about 18 months old, that meant I would be carrying it in my purse or in his diaper bag. If I left him with a babysitter or at his grandparents’ house, I had to make sure he had it in his diaper bag and that those left to care for him knew where to find it and how to use it.
Watching for Signs of Readiness in Children to Self-Carry Epinephrine

content: I knew that one day he would need to start learning how to self-carry. That age is different for every individual. Consider any other factors such as learning disabilities, mental health issues, or other situations that may or may not lend to a child being ready to successfully self-carry life-saving medication.
Before I had my son self-carry, I was mindful of his development and regularly asked myself a few questions about his readiness:
My Son’s Journey Through the Years

I continued carrying my son’s epinephrine with me for many years. But when he was about 8 years old and in a scouting program, I began to have him self-carry. As homeschoolers, this was the first time that he was truly “on his own” away from home and away from mom being there to carry for him. He was at scouts for about an hour at a time. As he grew through the years and would go to a friend’s house to play or participate in other extracurricular programs, he continued to self-carry.  More frequently, and for longer periods of time.
bullets: Will he keep it on his person and not take it off/out to show others, play with, or otherwise potentially lose it, break it, and so forth?
Does he understand this is a life-saving medication and not for play or use with other people?
Does he understand when and how to use the device?
Does he feel comfortable asking for help from an adult?

I continued carrying my son’s epinephrine with me for many years. But when he was about 8 years old and in a scouting program, I began to have him self-carry. As homeschoolers, this was the first time that he was truly “on his own” away from home and away from mom being there to carry for him. He was at scouts for about an hour at a time. As he grew through the years and would go to a friend’s house to play or participate in other extracurricular programs, he continued to self-carry.  More frequently, and for longer periods of time.

content: Some of his first epinephrine auto-injector holders were a style that looked like what we called “fanny packs” during my own childhood. He felt confident and proud of the carriers we bought for him to use. That was very important to us and to him. We didn’t want him to be ashamed or embarrassed and end up hiding the devices or not bring them with him.

There was a point in the preteen years that he began to feel self-conscious about the “fanny pack” style of epinephrine carrier. We searched many different websites to find something he could once again feel confident in and proud of. This one was made for diabetic people that were athletic, and it was meant to be worn on the leg. We found that it would fit his needs just great. His epinephrine fit as if it was made just for the job, and he was happy that he could wear it on his leg. He thought this carrier was “cool,” which was a win for all of us.

content: Fast forward into the teen years, and once again, the current carrier that was previously “cool” was now needing a replacement. This time, it was the epinephrine device that we opted to change out instead of the carrier itself. In younger years, he loved people recognizing his carrier and it being a discussion piece and tool for education and awareness. For him that brought an added level of comfort and decreased anxiety. But as a teen, he wanted to be seen just as everyone else and blend in. We switched brands of auto-injectors to a new one that “talks,” giving instructions for administration, and fits in your pocket!
bullets: Epinephrine comes in packages of two and should not be separated. Always carry two.
Most devices come with a trainer. Use the trainer often to keep on top of confidence in administration, as well as to train others in the event they need to step in and assist.

Check expiration dates. When purchasing, a rule of thumb in our family is to make sure the new device has an expiration at least one year out. Sometimes we are lucky, and they have a date even further out than a year.
Keep at a temperature between 68 and 77 degrees Fahrenheit. Read the package your brand of epinephrine comes in, as it may vary. Never submit your devices to extreme heat or cold.
Do not leave your epinephrine in a vehicle. This coincides with potential submission to extreme weather.

When traveling, keep devices on your person or in your carry-on. We have taken extra injectors with us when traveling that we check with our baggage, but we always have some on our person as well in the event of an emergency. You never know when you may be separated from your luggage.

Ask your allergist for multiple sets as needed. For us, this means a set for my son to have on his person, one set for me to have at home, and a third set that his coaches on high school sports teams keep for him in the team medic bag.

sections.heading: The Ultimate Goal: Always Have Immediate Access to Epinephrine
content: Your journey may have some similarities and some differences. No two journeys will be the same. Some children may have other factors that weigh in, changing the trajectory of when and how medication is self-carried. What is important is that your child always has immediate access to life-saving medication. While the goal is to eventually help them to be self-sufficient advocates, it is important to remember the ultimate task at hand: to simply have epinephrine readily available at all times.
